AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States District Court: court that calculated the criminal history and sentenced Rogelio Valero-De La Rosa, determined the advisory guideline range, mentioned in the context of a plea agreement and 'fast track' program
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States: country where Rogelio Valero-De La Rosa was removed from and later found, country with laws regarding re-entry after removal, referenced in the context of a plea agreement and 'fast track' program, seeks to enforce the plea agreement, party to the motion for summary judgment
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Bureau of Prisons: entity responsible for holding Rogelio Valero-De La Rosa in custody
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Mexico: country where Rogelio Valero-De La Rosa is a native and citizen
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Department of Homeland Security: department whose Secretary can grant permission to re-enter the United States, handled application for derivative citizenship
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Attorney General: official who authorized early disposition programs, including 'fast track' initiatives, and can grant permission to re-enter the United States
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Sentencing Commission: issuer of guidelines for sentencing, including provisions for cultural assimilation and recency points
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States District Judge: judge who decides on sentencing and downward departures in 'fast track' cases
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Magistrate Judge: judge who recommends acceptance of guilty pleas in 'fast track' programs, prepared Report and Recommendation
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Sentencing Guidelines: guidelines used for calculating criminal history points and applying applicable guidelines, consulted in determining sentence, include provisions for downward departures based on cultural assimilation
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Rogelio Valero-De La Rosa: defendant who was sentenced to 90 months of imprisonment and had no questions or objections regarding the sentence
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Probation Office: office that received the defendant's statement and prepared the PSR report documenting his background, responded to objections, disagreed with certain calculations regarding Rogelio Valero-De La Rosa's case, provided Supplemental Addendum
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Court of Appeals for the F: appellate court giving weight to defendant's statements at the plea colloquy
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Department of Justice: department whose attorney is authorized to offer 'fast track' programs in exchange for guilty pleas and waiver of certain rights
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States District Court for the Sou: court where Rogelio Valero-De La Rosa's plea was entered, rearraignment took place, and his sworn statements were made
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Congress: legislative body that intended sentencing disparity reductions through guidelines and amendments, acknowledging disparities caused by early disposition programs
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE: agency conducting interview with defendant Rogelio Valero-De La Rosa, involved in immigration enforcement
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Rio Grande: river crossed by the defendant to illegally enter the United States at Laredo, Texas
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Laredo: city in Texas where the defendant's family resides and where he attempted to reunite with them
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Texas: state in the United States where the defendant re-entered illegally to be with his family
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Citizenship and Immigratio: part of the Department of Homeland Security that handled the application for derivative citizenship
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Plea Agreement: agreement between Rogelio Valero-De La Rosa and the government, including waiver of certain rights, mentioned in the context of a 'fast track' downward departure request
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Plea Agreement Addendum: document signed by Rogelio Valero-De La Rosa, confirming understanding of rights and provisions of the United States Sentencing Commission's Guidelines Manual
